job_title: Phlebotomist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Pay Inpatient experience Nurses and patient appreciation is constant You feel like you’re needed and actually make a difference especially when patients wait and only request you to draw them.
cons: Management is horrible. Mostly toxic and manipulative. They make you sign a write up that has a false narrative and scare you in believing that union involvement won’t make a difference. I had to take time from my shift to prove management wrong. Then they threaten me with a second write up from another manager for not drawing patients when this person was the one originally notifying me about the write up. Not expecting me to stand up for myself. They had to go back 3 times deleting a few lines each time I proved them wrong until there was nothing left. Didn’t even apologize for their actions. Union calls me till this day for it. Multiple employed staff on emotional distress leave directly related to how management handles their staff . They make empty promises of securing a better time especially after a year of employment. Then they won’t give it to you just because a manager that hasn’t met you doesn’t like you so you end up not getting it even though I’m always drawing everyone’s hard stick. They demand your number of draws have to increase every time. No more than 15 minutes with a patient even though it’s a hard stick. Patient quantity over quality is a sad reality when not every patient is the same nor is every patient situation.

job_title: Fundraiser in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: RN Clinical Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Keck is a good place to work in terms of collaboration, autonomy, benefits and clinical practice. The doctors are excellent, very kind, responsive and value collaborative/team work. The clinical aspect of work is great however staff is burdened with complex insurance matters with not enough supporting staff. RN's have too many responsibilities that are not clinical. Patients are very complex medically and socially.
The work culture is excellent here. There is a lot of support, acknowledgement and a human aspect in respect to work-life balance. The benefits are great as well.
cons:
Pay is not competitive enough to stay here long
Not enough staff
Too many hurdles to deal with insurance matters which is 70% of the work

job_title: Executive Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Overall, USC is a great place to work at. The benefits were good, if visiting campus 15% off merch and campus food cafeteria. The greatest benefit if you have over a certain amount of years of service, you can attend USC and child as well. 
The majority of the staff where I worked were professional. My immediate supervisor (MD) that I worked for was very professional and understanding. The front desk staff were not so friendly and only formed a click of theirs. 
Pay was very decent, close to home, and continued education on campus! 
I loved it!
cons: I can't think of any.

Parking isn't great, operational improvements are slow, computer hardware is outdated and due for an upgrade, and the hiring process is a bit cumbersome.

cons: Huge turn over rate, constant changes in management, management not in touch. Extreme pay discrepancy across the board. People with bad work ethic end up staying.

job_title: Office Administrator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great teamwork great environment at keck

job_title: Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner in San Diego, CA
pros: Intelligent, devoted colleagues/members of interdisciplinary team.

review_title: If you're administrator, don't even consider this place
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Working for the USC brand has some cache in Southern California. The physicians are mostly excellent, so at least you can believe in what you're selling the public in the way of quality healthcare.
cons: Incredibly toxic environment of favoritism that isn't based on professional merit and sexism that goes unchecked. Childish, incompetent senior leadership with no accountability. Your annual review will be conducted by one person and it will be their opinion of you without input from any other coworkers/peers. You'll be working in a neighborhood so dangerous that leadership discourages employees from walking around except in groups. You'll be forced to pay for your own parking. There are no growth opportunities - people go years without promotions. HR is useless and has high turn-over, so you can expect retaliation if you seek assistance from them. You may be sweet-talked into taking a job here with the promise of the USC tuition benefit, but since the most valuable degree programs at USC are full-time and you'll be an hour's drive away from UPC campus, you can forget about using that benefit. There are a lot of other healthcare providers in the Los Angeles area, and if you're any kind of administrator, Keck is the worst one to work for. Beware!

job_title: Quality Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Benefits
Discounts
The name
Resume buffer
Free swag
Different departments
cons:
Politics
Disorganization 
Lack of communication 
Chain of command not clear

job_title: ICU RN BSN in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This is a great teaching hospital and there’s a lot of potential to grow as a nurse. I’ve meat a lot of interesting people there.
cons: While Keck is a good hospital and provides good patient care, there are minuses. Beware that different units have different cultures. If you are an RN, especially a new grad, please avoid 7 South ICU. Beware of their charge nurses, as they can make your life miserable. Also beware of some people who kind of come with the unit. Even nurses from other ICUs who ever get to float there, will tell you that this is not a good environment. They also tend to eat their young. If you want to work at Keck go to liver transplant, or 8 W or anywhere else!

job_title: Chart Auditor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Nice and clean facility. The work was low stress and easy.
cons: Catty coworkers full of drama and gossip. It's driving me crazy. People here are obnoxious and not professional at all. They form cliques and its like high school. I was so excited to work for Keck because I see the commercials on TV. But these people take their job for granted and complain about every little thing. They are very rude to me just because I take my job seriously. We are here to work people!

review_title: Poor management; revolving door of employees
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Decent money and benefits; nice cafeteria.  Valet parking was cheap.  Good gift store.
cons: Management does not know what they are doing and they are completely out of touch with their employees.  Mediocrity is praised and thinking outside the box is discouraged.  The supervisors can claim that you did something wrong even if you didn't and you can't do anything about it.  They waste so much money on stupid things like newsletters that nobody reads but the desks, chairs, restrooms, and especially the software, is antiquated.  If you are stupid but good at flying under the radar and not making waves, this would be perfect for you.  However, if you are innovative and outgoing, you will not last long.

job_title: M S W/Researcher/Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I have been at USC a total of 28 years. 20 years at the Health Science and 8 years at the University Park Campus.  I earned my Bachelor of Arts in Cultural Anthropology and and my Master's of Social Work with a concentation in Community, Organization, Planning and Administration (COPA). I love USC and it's the best place to work on earth and the largest employer in California.
cons: Parking is a challenge at USC HSC.  I pay approximately $1200.00/year for an annual permit.

review_title: You don't even feel the toxicity until you leave
job_title: Staff Person in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Prestigious institution, leading edge, entrepreneurial, pay, benefits, resources, some caring individuals, challenging work environment, interesting patients to take care of, academic center
cons: Weak leadership in SVP office that drives away competent folks, president of university is thin skinned, many doctors are arrogant, some entitled people make it grueling to work with them.

job_title: Medical Transcriptionist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits, good pay, my manager was the best.
cons: They laid 200 of us off at once without warning and without having a chance to say goodbye to any of our coworkers.    They laid off 200 more without warning the next month.  Many employees, from nurses to secretaries, now have to do twice as much work, and I am not exaggerating.

review_title: Excellent co-workers, solid leadership, important mission. Proud to be a Trojan!
job_title: Anonymous in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Excellent co-workers, solid leadership and a chance to make a real difference. Plenty of opportunities to make a significant impact, whatever your role.
Leaders are committed to ongoing improvement and are open to change.
Collaborative, open door culture
Decent work/life balance
Top-notch benefits
Growing

Proud to be a part of a diverse team co-workers that are committed to providing world-class care for the most acute patients.
cons:
Parking can be a challenge at some locations.
Some legacy processes and systems still need to be updated.

job_title: Front Office Manager in East Los Angeles, CA
pros: The pros were that the hospital is apart of USC so you are eligible for a tuition benefit if you are a full time employee.
cons: The cons are that it’s a healthcare system that is still trying to identify themselves as the “best hospital in Los Angeles”, but leadership does not have a shared/mutual understanding of what that is.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Pay package is good; its unionized expiring 2021. Union is strong.
cons: Punitive response, threats, and microaggression for minor infractions but upper rank USC employees have had bad (illegal) actions and press and it takes long for administration to weed them out. Usual horizontal bullying. Little or no response to incident reports. Usual surrender to hostile family demands. Some nurses are protected by union.

job_title: Clerical in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits, vacation and sick time. Friendly coworkers. I don't know what else to say other than that. I wish i had more pros to provide.
cons: They lay off staff frequently and then expect to have the remaining staff work triple the amount of work without compensation. If you have an outstanding annual review, do not expect a raise. Stress level is extremely high for receptionists and appointment schedulers.  Some departments do not enforce breaks to staff. Keck will not pay staff overtime. Extremely high stress. Seniority means nothing here. No room for growth.

job_title: Help Desk Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It's as if it where family, indeed the Trojan family.  One may not know all of what they're doing, but someone does.  Commitment to service, excellent service, sharp and crisp, with sound judgments --treating both one's own department equal to the other.  Was a pleasure working there.
cons: If any such exist.  It was simply that I had to travel, for which I resigned.  The power to stay was out of my control.

job_title: Support Coordinator in East Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great coworkers. Staff very focused on patient centered care and patient experience.  Healthcare workers can now be part of union (reasons union is required at all is stated in cons).
cons: High turnover rate at the managerial level. I have seen many supervisors, administrators, and directors come and go. Poor pay and management is complicit in preventing raises.

job_title: Staff RN in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Excellent pay and benefits package. Free USC tickets
Up to 10%. 401 k match when you contribute 5% of base pay.
cons: No checks and balance for nurses in power.  British charge RN  in 7 south rude and vindictive towards her own staff.  High demand job.  No time to rest, unless you're the charge RN.

job_title: Data Management Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Keck Medicine of USC was recently recognized as one of the best hospital systems in the nation. The work you do makes an impact in real time. Patient and employee satisfaction scores remain in good standing.
cons: Limtied opportunties for growth, primarily on the business/administration side of the hospital. Top-level directors and executives stay in their positions for years and once they see your impact in an entry/mid-level role, they keep you there.

job_title: Training in East Los Angeles, CA
pros: Lots of resources. Over 100 year old company. Lots of dedicated doctors and staff.
cons: Highly political. Some powerful people are obviously incompetent and destructive and yet they flourish. Because of the access to money the organization does not make smart fiscal decisions.  The non-healthcare support staff are housed in buildings far off campus that are less than optimal.

job_title: Health Information in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very helpful, friendly and encouraging work environment.Supportive training. Encouraged to work independently with no supervision within first week of employment.
cons: Traffic, hours, politics, parking, middle management. lack of adequate restroom facilities in old location. Since then the department has been relocated.

job_title: Technical in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Decent opportunities for advancement if your willing to play the game.
cons: Lack of quality leadership, poor communication, political, favoritism, diversity issues within certain sectors, militant, poor training.

review_title: Barely mediocre? You'll do just fine here!
job_title: Secretary in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Decent wages; there's a cafeteria on site and you get an employee discount; other than that, I can't think of anything
cons: Management caters to the lazy and stupid --- if you're smart and ask questions, you get in trouble for being "annoying" and "insubordinate".  You will get bad scores on your annual review and you will get judged on competencies that are not relevant to your job.

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Wonderful place to work, with supportive staff and incredible doctors! I loved working with all the specialists and physician leadership here at USC. Very innovative and collaborative group aimed at delivering the best care to their patients.
cons: Need more stability in upper management to continue on with the vision of great care

review_title: It looks great on a resume, but not worth the headache

job_title: Human Resources in Los Angeles, CA

cons: A lack of strategic vision at the leadership level, coupled with poor financial management (and the constant threat  of hiring freezes and layoffs) make this an extremely challenging environment for anyone who is accustomed to a degree of professionalism and competence in their workplace.

review_title: Colleagues in this organization are petty, complacent and engage in bullying behavior
